intro: Abronia glabra, commonly known as the smooth sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial shrub that typically reaches heights of 10 to 20 centimeters. The plant produces small, bright yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are linear and often covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in its arid habitat. Abronia glabra is adapted to sandy and rocky soils, making it a characteristic species of desert and coastal environments.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abronia glabra is primarily native to the southeastern United States, particularly Florida and parts of Georgia. distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abronia glabra was mainly introduced to the coastal regions of the Pacific Northwest in the United States. It was first documented in Oregon during the early 20th century as a result of human activity, including the movement of soil and plant material. This plant has since established itself in sandy and dune environments, often near the shoreline. Its introduction has raised concerns due to its potential to outcompete native vegetation in these sensitive ecosystems.
